Netanyahu stated that this is not just an operation or a round, but a sustained effort. He also stressed the need to unite the country to achieve victory over Hamas, delaying accountability for the October 7 attack until the conclusion of the ongoing war. Israeli forces have gained control of the Palestinian Legislative Council building in Gaza City, which has been under Hamas's control since 2007. The Israeli military reported targeting a group of Hamas fighters embedded among civilians at Gaza's Al-Quds Hospital, resulting in the deaths of approximately 21 terrorists. On the Palestinian side, the Health Ministry reported that Israeli attacks have resulted in the deaths of 11,180 Palestinians, including 4,609 children and 3,100 women, with 28,200 individuals injured. There have also been challenges in updating daily reports on the death toll due to Israeli attacks on hospitals.

item.title: “The Answer is Modi”: Jaishankar credits PM’s leadership for socioeconomic revolution in India
item.description: India has undergone a socioeconomic revolution in the past decade, and External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar attributes this to the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. PM Modi's initiatives, such as Beti Padhao Beti Bachao, Jandhan Yojana, Awas Yojana, Digital India, Startup India, and Skill India campaigns, have had a significant impact on the country. These efforts have led to transformative changes in India, including financial inclusion, building houses, promoting education for girls, and fostering digital innovation. The government has also focused on creating new universities and colleges, contributing to the socioeconomic revolution. The evolving India-UK relationship is being reframed to unlock the unrealized potential between the two nations. EAM Jaishankar's visit to the UK aims to strengthen the growing bilateral partnership and explore new convergences. India and the UK are also in negotiations for a Free Trade Agreement.

item.title: Hope to find a landing point that works for both of us: Jaishankar on India-UK FTA
item.description: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar has emphasized that a free trade agreement (FTA) is a key focus of the India-UK relationship and expressed hope for a mutually beneficial outcome in negotiations. Speaking at a special Diwali reception in London, Jaishankar highlighted the positive impact of the bilateral relationship and urged the Indian diaspora in the UK to promote the story of India's development. He also mentioned the ongoing negotiations for an enhanced trade partnership and the potential for an FTA to strengthen ties between both countries. Jaishankar is currently on a five-day official visit to the UK to review bilateral ties. The India-UK comprehensive strategic partnership was launched in 2021, and negotiations for an FTA have been underway since January last year.

item.title: Deportation of undocumented Afghans alters Balochistan’s socio-economic landscape: Report
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The deportation of undocumented Afghan citizens from Pakistan is having a significant impact on the socio-economic dynamics in Balochistan, particularly in the city of Quetta. Many of those being deported are Pashtun, who had integrated into local Pashtun communities. The departure of these individuals has disrupted their lives and affected the communities that had embraced them. The Hazara community in Balochistan, which saw an increase in numbers after the Taliban's takeover of Kabul, is also facing a crisis as undocumented Hazaras have left for Afghanistan. This has exacerbated concerns among those who had fled oppression by the Afghan Taliban. The economic ramifications are being felt in Quetta, where some refugees played a vital role in the city's economy as laborers and consumers. Their departure has led to an economic downturn. The introduction of a passport requirement for crossing into Afghanistan has also disrupted businesses and family connections in Chaman, leading to protests. The social impact of the deportations is significant, as many Afghans had been part of the society for years, marrying and developing community ties. The deportations may strain cross-border kinships, diminish cultural and social contributions, and potentially destabilize local economies. Baloch nationalist parties, who were previously opposed to Afghan refugees, have remained silent on the issue this time. There are allegations that a large number of Afghans have been issued Pakistani identity cards, and there is speculation that these cards will be blocked and cancelled in the next phase, which could inadvertently affect Pakistani citizens in Balochistan. A careful and humane approach is necessary to prevent further disruption to the lives of both Afghan refugees and Balochistan's citizens.

item.title: Soccer-Denmark’s injured Man United pair Hojlund, Eriksen withdraw from squad
item.description: Denmark's Manchester United players Rasmus Hojlund and Christian Eriksen will miss their next two Euro 2024 qualifiers due to injuries. Hojlund will be out until late November with a muscle injury, while Eriksen will be sidelined for a month with a knee injury. Denmark, currently in second place in Group H, will qualify for the tournament if they defeat Slovenia. Hojlund was replaced during a Premier League match, while Eriksen was substituted during the first half. Manchester United is already dealing with several other player absences.

item.title: Syria allows UN to keep delivering aid from Turkey
item.description: Syria has granted the United Nations (UN) permission to continue delivering aid to opposition-held areas in the country's northwest for another three months. Initially, after an earthquake caused significant casualties in Turkey and Syria, the UN was allowed to provide aid through Turkish border crossings for a period of three months, which has now been extended for a third time until February 13th. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs highlighted the importance of this cross-border operation, as it reaches around 2.5 million people monthly with critical assistance and protection services. Syria's mission to the UN confirmed the extension of the UN's use of the Bab al-Salam and Al Ra'ee crossings. The UN had also been using the Bab al-Hawa crossing since 2014, but authorization from the UN Security Council expired in mid-July. However, shortly after, the Syrian government allowed the UN to continue using Bab al-Hawa for an additional six months. In total, over 4,200 trucks carrying UN aid have utilized these border crossings so far this year.

item.title: Israeli tanks outside Gaza hospital, surgeon says, pleading ‘Someone should stop this’
item.description: Israeli tanks have positioned themselves at the gates of Gaza City's main hospital, Al Shifa, resulting in patients, including newborns, dying due to a lack of fuel and power. The siege of the hospital and the lack of resources have caused the death of 32 patients in the last three days. Gaza health ministry spokesperson Ashraf Al-Qidra stated that there are still around 650 patients in need of evacuation. Israel claims that the hospital is being used as a headquarters by Hamas fighters, an accusation denied by Hamas. President Joe Biden expressed his hope for less intrusive action at the hospital and stressed the need to protect it. The conflict between Israel and Hamas has resulted in thousands of deaths and the displacement of two-thirds of Gaza's population. Fighting has also occurred at Al Quds hospital, causing it to cease functioning. Israel alleges that terrorists were shot from the hospital entrance in return fire. The conflict has raised concerns about its potential spread beyond Gaza, with clashes on the Israeli-Lebanese border and the United States launching airstrikes on Iran-linked militia targets in Syria.

item.title: Hamas armed wing discussed releasing 70 hostages in return for 5-day truce
item.description: The armed wing of Hamas, a Palestinian militant group, has stated to Qatari mediators that they are willing to release up to 70 women and children in Gaza in exchange for a five-day truce. The ceasefire would need to include a complete halt in hostilities, as well as the provision of aid and humanitarian relief throughout the Gaza Strip. Hamas has accused Israel of delaying and avoiding the terms of the agreement.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.

item.title: Brazil aims to expand rail system with funds from prior contracts
item.description: The Brazilian government plans to expand its railway network with a 40 billion reais ($8 billion) fund, funded by removing discounts given to rail companies under previous government contracts. The discounts were given to iron ore miner Vale and logistics companies Rumo and MRS in 2022 under the government of former President Jair Bolsonaro. These contracts did not go through the normal public bidding process, and the companies were allowed to make an advance payment deducting unamortized assets from their owed concession payments. The government claims that the companies owe an additional 40 billion reais ($8.1 billion) in unpaid concession payments. While Rumo has agreed to pay, Vale and MRS are still disputing the matter in court. Once the court's decision is made, the government plans to arrange any payments with the companies. The funds will be used to finance the construction of new railways and extend existing ones, with the goal of increasing rail freight transportation from 17% to 40% of Brazil's total freight, including iron ore.

item.title: Biden, China’s Xi will discuss communication, competition at APEC summit
item.description: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit on November 15. The White House stated that the leaders will discuss strengthening communication and managing competition between the two countries. Biden believes that face-to-face diplomacy is crucial for managing the complex relationship, according to White House National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan. The meeting aims to curb tensions and cover various global issues, including the Israel-Hamas conflict, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, North Korea's ties with Russia, Taiwan, the Indo-Pacific, human rights, fentanyl, artificial intelligence, and trade and economic relations.

item.title: Jaishankar appreciates James Cleverly’s unwavering support for India-UK strategic partnership
item.description: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar met UK Home Secretary James Cleverly to discuss the strong strategic partnership between India and the UK. They focused on mobility, skills, and talent as key factors in cooperative development. The leaders also addressed shared concerns such as extremism, economic offenses, trafficking, and security. Jaishankar also had discussions with UK Defence Secretary Grant Shapps to enhance defense and security cooperation. The Make in India initiative was highlighted as an opportunity for collaboration with British partners. They also exchanged views on global security challenges. Jaishankar greeted newly appointed UK Foreign Secretary David Cameron and expressed appreciation for the growing bilateral partnership between India and the UK. The visit aimed to give new impetus to friendly ties between the two countries. India and the UK are currently negotiating a Free Trade Agreement.

Raducanu began light training in August and aims to make a comeback in the next season, with the Australian Grand Slam starting on January 15th.

item.title: Fidelity rolls out suite of new ETFs, slashes fees
item.description: Fidelity has launched six new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and reduced management fees on a third of its existing ETF lineup. This year, asset managers have already introduced 419 ETFs, bringing them closer to surpassing the record of 475 in 2021. This week is expected to see the introduction of at least a dozen new products, including five actively-managed ETFs by Ark Invest and 21Shares AG focused on bitcoin, ethereum futures, and blockchain technology. Fidelity's new ETFs cover various portfolios and offer lower fees compared to the industry average for actively managed ETFs.

item.title: Google’s expert in US antitrust trial defends billions paid to device makers
item.description: An expert witness called by Google in the ongoing antitrust trial testified that the company's multi-billion dollar payments to Apple and other parties are normal competitive behavior and not an abuse of monopoly. Kevin Murphy, a professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, argued that Apple and others played Google and Microsoft off against each other to secure large payments. The government has accused Google of paying billions to ensure its search is the default on smartphones and browsers, alleging it as an abuse of monopoly. Murphy also stated that these payments often result in benefits to users, such as cheaper phones or better data plans. He added that while Microsoft had the majority of preinstalled browser defaults, its Bing search engine only received 15% of search queries. The trial is expected to conclude this week.

ICBC's U.S. arm was targeted in a ransomware attack that disrupted trades in the U.S. Treasury market. The hack was extensive, causing the firm's corporate email system to malfunction. ICBC did not immediately comment on the incident. The attack raises concerns about the resilience of the $26 trillion Treasury market and may attract regulatory scrutiny. LockBit has emerged as the world's leading ransomware threat, targeting numerous organizations globally. Some companies opt to pay ransoms to quickly regain access to their systems and avoid reputational damage.

item.title: More than 40 calls received in 48 hours about injured and distressed animals due to Diwali firecrackers, says official
item.description: Over the past 48 hours, authorities in Mumbai have received over 40 calls regarding injured or displaced animals as a result of firecrackers being burst during Diwali. The animals affected include cats, dogs, birds, and reptiles. Despite the Bombay High Court's directive to only burst firecrackers between 8pm and 10pm, air quality has worsened. Animal rescue teams from various organizations are on alert, expecting an increase in cases of distressed animals that may continue for weeks after the festival. So far, six birds, two snakes, and a turtle with burn injuries have been rescued. Citizens can report wildlife distress to the forest department helpline and domestic animal distress to the BMC helpline.

item.title: Rising temperatures, longer monsoon drive Bangladesh’s worst dengue outbreak
item.description: Bangladesh is experiencing its worst-ever outbreak of dengue fever, with a death toll of 1,476 and over 291,000 infected. Experts attribute the severe outbreak to rising temperatures and a longer monsoon season caused by climate change, which create ideal breeding conditions for the dengue-spreading mosquito. This year's death toll is more than five times that of 2022 and the highest since authorities began tracking the disease in 2000. The Aedes mosquito, which spreads dengue, is adapting to the changing climate patterns, leading to the disease's spread in all 64 districts of the country. Vector surveillance is now needed year-round to monitor the disease's spread. There is no specific vaccine or drug for dengue, but early detection and proper medical care can reduce deaths to less than 1% of those infected. Hospitals in Bangladesh are struggling to cope with the influx of patients and a shortage of intravenous fluids.

item.title: Oil gains more than 1% as OPEC report dampens demand concerns

OPEC stated that oil market fundamentals remained strong and attributed the drop in prices to speculators. The organization slightly raised its 2023 forecast for global oil demand growth and maintained its high prediction for 2024. The report countered negative sentiment around Chinese demand and increased demand growth forecasts for this year. Last week, the US Energy Information Administration lowered its projection for crude oil production and predicted a decrease in demand. Additionally, weak economic data from China raised fears of faltering demand. However, analysts believe that oil prices may have reached a bottom and expect Saudi Arabia and Russia to continue their voluntary supply cuts into next year, limiting downside potential. The next OPEC+ meeting is scheduled for November 26.

Spot gold increased by 0.4% to $1,934.25 per ounce, while U.S. gold futures gained 0.1% to $1,938.50. The upcoming release of U.S. consumer prices index (CPI) data and producer price index data will be closely watched. If the inflation data exceeds expectations, gold may face downward pressure due to the possibility of a rate hike. However, if the data aligns with expectations, gold could trade above $1,950. It's important to note that higher interest rates can reduce the appeal of gold as it doesn't generate yield. The market currently predicts an 86% chance of the Fed keeping rates unchanged in December. Last week, gold prices dipped due to reduced safe-haven demand and a hawkish tone from Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Moody's recently changed the outlook on the U.S. government's ratings to "negative" from "stable." Spot silver fell by 1% to $21.99 per ounce, while platinum gained 1.1% to $849.49 and palladium fell by 1% to $953.44, near a five-year low.

item.title: Mexico’s Ebrard to stay in ruling party, avoiding split
item.description: Former Mexican foreign minister Marcelo Ebrard has announced that he will remain with the ruling leftist National Regeneration Movement (Morena) and will not seek the presidency in 2024 with an opposition party. Ebrard had previously rejected the results of Morena's presidential primaries and had not ruled out the possibility of seeking the presidency with the center-left opposition Citizens' Movement (MC) party. However, he has now reached an understanding with Morena's presidential candidate, former Mexico City mayor Claudia Sheinbaum. Ebrard stated that he would continue to pursue the presidency in the future but acknowledged that it was not feasible for next year. As a former socially progressive mayor of Mexico City, Ebrard decriminalized abortion and legalized same-sex marriage in the capital. He also played a key role in negotiations with the Trump and Biden administrations on trade and immigration.

item.title: EU plan for new Russia sanctions to go to members this week – Borrell
item.description: The European Union is finalizing plans for a proposed 12th package of sanctions on Russia, which will include a ban on diamonds. The European Commission could approve the package as early as Wednesday, after which it will be discussed and approved by the Council of the EU. The EU has already imposed 11 packages of sanctions on Russia since the invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, with measures targeting various sectors and over 1,800 individuals and entities. The new package will also include export bans, actions to tighten oil price caps, and measures to combat circumvention. The timing for the proposal is expected to be early next week.

item.title: Sweden says some of its citizens have left Gaza, more to leave

item.title: Odia actress held for ‘misbehaving’ with woman writer
item.description: Actress Mousumi Nayak has been arrested by police in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, for allegedly demanding money and misbehaving with writer Banasmita Pati. The arrest was made based on a complaint filed by Pati. Previously, Nayak had lodged a complaint against Pati, accusing her of failing to repay a loan of Rs 5.08 lakh. However, both parties had reached a compromise, with Pati returning the money and Nayak agreeing not to tarnish her image. Despite this, Nayak made statements against Pati and her family in the media, and also filed a "false case" against her. Nayak allegedly sent threatening messages to Pati and her family as well. Nayak has admitted to the offenses and has been arrested under various sections of the Indian Penal Code.

item.title: Israel combining land, air, naval forces in war, operating inside Gaza: IDF spokesperson
item.description: The Israeli Defense Force (IDF) spokesperson, Lt Col Richard Hecht, has stated that the IDF is operating in Gaza to ensure the safe release of 239 Israeli hostages. The IDF is utilizing land, air, and naval forces in their operations against Hamas in Gaza. Hecht emphasized that the conflict is with Hamas and not the people of Gaza. The IDF has repeatedly asked civilians in the Shati area to leave, using text messages, leaflets, and media messages. Hecht claimed that Hamas has built a dedicated city for terrorism under the Shati area and that the fighting will be intense in this complex urban warfare. The IDF also maintained a tactical pause to allow Gazan civilians to evacuate through the Rafah crossing. Additionally, the IDF reported that 21 members of a terror cell were killed after they opened fire at Israeli forces from Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City. The IDF stated that the cell was embedded among civilians and used the hospital as a base for their attack. The IDF returned fire, killing 21 operatives and damaging a tank. The IDF has criticized Hamas for using civilian structures, including hospitals, to carry out attacks.

item.title: Researchers give more insight into development of lupus in females
item.description: In lupus, an autoimmune disease, women are affected nine times more than males. The reasons behind this gender disparity have been unclear, but a recent study by Johns Hopkins Medicine has shed light on the role of the X chromosome and a specific genetic material called X-inactive specific transcript (XIST). The study found that XIST can trigger an immune response involving toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7), a protein in the immune system. This immune response contributes to the development and severity of lupus in women. The research suggests that XIST may play a role in promoting autoimmunity and could be a potential target for future therapies. Further studies are needed to explore XIST's involvement in other autoimmune conditions that predominantly affect women.

item.title: Odia actress held for ‘misbehaving’ with woman writer
item.description: Actress Mousumi Nayak has been arrested in Bhubaneswar for allegedly demanding money and misbehaving with writer Banasmita Pati. Nayak had initially filed a complaint against Pati, accusing her of failing to repay a loan. However, both parties reached a compromise and the money was returned. Despite this, Nayak continued to make statements against Pati and her family, and even lodged a false case against her. Nayak also allegedly sent threatening messages. She has been arrested and charged with various offenses, including criminal intimidation and extortion.

item.description: As a part of the 'Ek Diya Shaheedon Ke Naam' initiative, 11,000 earthen lamps were lit at the Gorakhnath temple in Uttar Pradesh to pay tribute to martyrs. Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath lit a lamp in the Bheem Sarovar area of the temple, and a cultural program was also organized as part of the initiative. The program was organized by the Bhojpuri Association of India.As a part of the 'Ek Diya Shaheedon Ke Naam' initiative, 11,000 earthen lamps were lit at the Gorakhnath Temple in Uttar Pradesh to pay tribute to martyrs. item.title: Delhi pollution: NDMC doubles parking fees to discourage use of private vehicles
item.description: The New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) has increased parking charges in an effort to discourage people from using private vehicles due to high pollution levels in the capital. There are 91 parking sites in the NDMC area, with 41 managed by the council and the rest outsourced. The increased charges will apply until January 31, 2024, in order to promote alternate modes of transportation. Presently, the NDMC charges Rs 20 per hour and a maximum of Rs 100 per day for four-wheelers, and Rs 10 per hour and a maximum of Rs 50 per day for two-wheelers. Monthly charges are fixed at Rs 2,000 for four-wheelers and Rs 1,000 for two-wheelers.

item.title: Rolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger goes pandal-hopping in Kolkata on Kali Pujo
item.description: Rock legend and Rolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger is currently in India, celebrating the festival of Diwali in Kolkata. He shared pictures on his official Instagram account, showcasing the sights and sounds of the festival. Jagger was seen dressed in a distinctive outfit while standing on the streets of Kolkata and posing with replicas of mythical bhoots artwork. He also posed with a statue of goddess Kali and shared a video of an artisan completing an idol of goddess Jagaddhatri. Fans and industry friends flooded the comment section of his photos. Jagger was recently spotted at the Eden Gardens watching an ICC World Cup match between England and Pakistan. Known for his iconic songs, Jagger was honored with a knighthood in 2002 for his contributions to popular music.

item.title: Kenya’s president urges progress on global plastics treaty
item.description: Negotiators at the third round of talks in Nairobi are urged to reach a deal on the world's first treaty to combat plastic pollution. The global plastic waste production is around 400 million metric tonnes per year, with less than 10% being recycled. Approximately 14 million metric tonnes of plastic end up in the ocean annually, alongside increasing amounts in landfills. Delegates will discuss potential measures for the treaty, focusing on the entire life cycle of plastics or prioritizing plastic waste management. Kenya advocates for a binding agreement on plastic production and usage and has implemented laws banning certain plastic uses since 2017. The plastic industry and oil and petrochemical exporters, such as Saudi Arabia, oppose curbing plastic use and argue for improved recycling and reuse. Majority of countries support advancing the negotiations, while a smaller group, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are attempting to hinder progress.

item.title: EU pledges ‘substantial’ contribution to COP28 climate damage fund
item.description: The European Union (EU) has announced that it will make a substantial financial contribution to a new international fund addressing the destruction caused by climate change. The fund, known as the "loss and damage" fund, will be launched during the United Nations COP28 climate summit in Dubai. The EU did not specify the size of its planned contribution. In addition to this, the EU will also commit funding to help countries meet the goal of tripling global renewable energy capacity by 2030. The move by the EU could pave the way for other deals at COP28, such as phasing out fossil fuels and reducing emissions. The UAE's incoming COP28 president welcomed the EU's announcement. So far, no country has made a specific financial pledge to the fund, although the US has signaled interest in contributing "several millions of dollars". High-income countries, including the UAE, are facing pressure to contribute to UN climate funds.

item.title: Indonesia presidential front-runner Prabowo criticises EU on deforestation
item.description: Presidential front-runner Prabowo Subianto of Indonesia criticized the European Union (EU) over its ban on palm oil imports and claimed that Europeans were also responsible for deforestation during colonial times. The EU recently passed a law to ban imports of commodities linked to forest destruction, including palm oil, which Indonesia is the largest producer of. Prabowo argued that while Indonesia has maintained good relations with Europe, the EU's ban on palm oil has created difficulties for selling other products such as coffee, tea, and cocoa. The EU, previously the third-largest buyer of Indonesian palm oil, did not immediately respond to Prabowo's comments. Prabowo further highlighted that during colonial rule, Europeans forced Indonesians to plant other crops such as tea, coffee, rubber, and cocoa, resulting in the destruction of forests. He emphasized the need for an equal playing field and expressed concern about the impact of the EU's deforestation law on Indonesia's annual exports. A task force comprising the EU, Indonesia, and Malaysia, the second-largest palm oil producer globally, has been formed to discuss the law.

item.title: Airports Authority of India issues caution notice on fraud job offers
item.description: The Airports Authority of India (AAI) has issued a press release warning the public about fraudulent job offers being circulated throughout the country. There have been numerous complaints reported through various channels, including emails and social media. The misinformation includes false details about job vacancies, exam questions, exam dates, result publication dates, and promises of jobs in exchange for payment. The AAI advises the public to only rely on the official AAI website for accurate information. They emphasize that application fees are only payable during online registration and no other payments are solicited at any recruitment stage. The public is cautioned not to fall victim to such falsehoods and is recommended to only visit the AAI website for accurate information. The AAI has clarified that they are not responsible for any losses or damages resulting from the actions of these fraudulent individuals. The public is urged to exercise caution and stay vigilant against misleading advertisements.

Japanese data showed that wholesale inflation had slowed, suggesting diminishing pressure on the yen. However, there was still concern about potential intervention from the Japanese government to strengthen the currency. The euro and sterling both gained slightly, with sterling also rising against the euro after news of changes in the UK government.

Higher interest rates tend to reduce the appeal of gold as it is a non-yielding asset. The Gaza health ministry stated that 32 patients had died in the past three days, and around 650 patients were still awaiting evacuation. However, Israel claims that the hospital is being used as a headquarters for Hamas fighters and accuses them of using patients as shields. The conflict has also raised concerns about its potential spread beyond Gaza, with clashes on Israel's border with Lebanon and the United States launching airstrikes on Iran-linked militias in Syria. The situation at Al Shifa hospital remains dire, with tanks stationed at the gates, Israeli fire targeting the hospital, and limited resources available. The conflict has sparked polarized reactions globally, with some countries condemning the Israeli response and the high civilian casualties. item.title: Brazilian police arrest third man suspected of links to Hezbollah
item.description: Brazilian police have arrested another man in connection with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, bringing the total number of detainees suspected of involvement with the group to three. The man was arrested in Brazil's capital, Brasilia, and his alleged link to the Iranian-backed group was already under investigation. Last week, two people were arrested in Sao Paulo as part of an operation to dismantle a suspected Hezbollah cell planning attacks on Jewish targets in Brazil. Hezbollah was founded in Lebanon in 1982 by Iran's Revolutionary Guards to fight against Israeli forces. It has been designated as a terrorist organization by several countries, including the United States and Argentina. Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro had planned to label Hezbollah a terrorist organization, but the move never materialized.

item.title: Noise levels breach permissible limits on Diwali night in Ranchi
item.description: Noise levels in the silence zones and commercial areas of Ranchi exceeded the permissible limits on Diwali night, according to data from the Jharkhand State Pollution Control Board. In the silence zones of Doranda and RIMS Bariatu, noise levels increased by 56% and 64.46 dB, respectively, compared to the average limit of 45 dB. Commercial areas such as Albert Ekka Chowk, Lalpur, and Ratu Road saw a spike of 34.9% to 37.8% in noise levels against the average limit of 60 dB. Ashok Nagar, a residential area, recorded a 43.3% increase in noise levels. The JSPCB observed that the maximum firecracker activity occurred within the permitted two-hour window from 8pm to 10pm. While the ban on firecrackers above 125 decibels helped control noise pollution, Ranchi's air quality also deteriorated during Diwali, with PM-10 levels exceeding the permissible limit.

item.title: Bhagat wins gold at Hulic Daihatsu Japan Para Badminton tournament
item.description: Pramod Bhagat, a para badminton player and Asian Games gold medallist, won a gold medal in the SL3 singles category at the Hulic Daihatsu Japan Para Badminton International Tournament in Tokyo. He defeated his compatriot Manoj Sarkar in the final. In mixed doubles, Bhagat and Manisha Ramdass lost to a Chinese pair, while Sukant Kadam won a bronze medal in the singles SL4 category. Other Indian players also secured medals in various categories. Nehal Gupta and Naveen Sivakumar won gold in men's doubles, Manisha Joshi won a bronze in women's SL3 category, and Thulasimathi Murugesan won silver in women's SU5 category. Manasi Joshi and Thulasimathi Murugesan teamed up to win gold in women's doubles.

item.title: India’s retail inflation eases to 4.87% in October
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.India's retail inflation in October eased to 4.87% from 5.02% in the previous month, moving closer to the central bank's target of 4%. Food inflation, which makes up nearly half of the consumer price basket, increased slightly to 6.61% in October compared to 6.56% in September. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has kept its key lending rate unchanged for the fourth consecutive policy meeting, stating its focus on bringing inflation close to the target.

item.title: 1st division now mandatory in Bachelor, Master degrees for IIM directors’ post; President can dissolve board
item.description: The Indian government has introduced new rules for the appointment of directors at Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs). The new norms require applicants to hold first-class degrees in both their bachelor's and master's, as well as a PhD or equivalent from a reputable institute. The president will also now be designated as the "visitor" to these prestigious institutions, granting them powers to appoint the chairperson of the board of governors, appoint and remove directors, and dissolve the board for non-compliance with directives. Previously, the board was solely responsible for director appointments. These changes aim to ensure that directors possess a distinguished academic record.

item.title: Shinde govt to provide arms licence seekers 3-day training in handling guns, a 1st for Maharashtra
item.description: The Maharashtra government in India has announced that it will offer training on handling and storing weapons to all individuals who apply for a weapons permit in the state. The training program will cover various aspects of weapon handling such as dismantling, cleaning, loading, and trigger control. While attendance is not mandatory, applicants can choose to opt for the training. The aim of the program is to ensure that permit holders know how to handle their weapons safely. The training will be conducted by the Maharashtra police's training directorate and will cost Rs 1,000 for each permit seeker. Applicants interested in the training will need to submit a written application to the commissioner of police or the police superintendent of the region. The training will be a three-day course, with sessions running from 9 am to 11.30 am.

item.title: MLA’s kin loses Rs 79,492 while making online payment to buy sweets
item.description: A 31-year-old family member of an MLA from Maharashtra's Thane district lost Rs. 79,492 while trying to make an online payment for sweets ordered from a shop. The victim placed an order and received a QR code for payment. However, when she tried to make the payment, she received a call from someone claiming to be from the sweet shop who asked her to make additional transactions for completing the payment. After realizing that Rs. 79,012 had been debited from her account in two installments, the victim filed a complaint with the police. A case has been registered against an unidentified person for cheating under Indian Penal Code section 420 and provisions of the Information Technology Act.

item.title: CM Dhami visits Uttarkashi tunnel collapse site; rescue efforts on, loose debris being stabilised
item.description: Uttarakhand Chief Minister Pushkar Singh Dhami has arrived at the site in Uttarkashi where 40 workers are trapped after a tunnel collapsed on the Brahmakhal-Yamunotri national highway. Rescuers have been in contact with the trapped workers and have provided them with food and water. Efforts are being made to stabilize the loose debris, and personnel from multiple agencies are involved in the rescue operations. The trapped laborers are from various states, and authorities are optimistic about their safety as enough oxygen has been made available to them.

item.title: Congress talks big about caste census but its Madhya Pradesh candidate list lacks OBC names
item.description:
Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the Congress party's efforts in promoting social justice and its impact on the caste composition of its candidates for the upcoming Madhya Pradesh assembly election. The party has appointed a Dalit leader as its national president and has been advocating for a caste census. However, an analysis of the party's nominated candidates reveals that substantial changes have not been made in its candidate nomination policy.
The Congress has allocated 36% of the tickets to upper castes, which comprise only around 10% of the state's population. In contrast, OBCs, representing more than half of the state's population, have been given only 27% of the tickets. This indicates that while there is a symbolic shift towards social justice, there have been no substantive changes in the candidate nomination policy.
The article also highlights the dominance of certain jatis (castes) among the Congress candidates. More than half of the nominated candidates belong to five jatis: Rajput, Brahmin, Gond, Bhil, and Jatav/Ahirwar. Rajputs and Brahmins make up a significant portion of the nominations, with Rajputs comprising around 14% and Brahmins around 13% of the total candidates.
Gonds and Bhils, as well as Jains, Baniyas, and Gurjars, also receive notable political representation. Among Scheduled Castes, the Jatav/Ahirwar castes have the highest number of nominations. However, the Congress has not been able to implement its aggressive stance on caste issues within the party, as the traditional upper-caste local elite still have influence over nominations.
The article concludes by suggesting that the Congress may face electoral consequences if it fails to address these disparities in caste representation.

item.title: US Senator Tim Scott drops out of 2024 Presidential race, suspends campaign
item.description: US Senator Tim Scott has dropped out of the 2024 presidential race, stating that he has no intentions of supporting another contender for the Republican nomination. Scott made the announcement on Fox News's "Sunday Night in America" and also rejected the possibility of running as the Republican party's national ticket's running partner in 2024. He had previously announced his candidacy for the 2024 US Presidential elections in May, emerging as the latest opponent to Donald Trump. Other Republican candidates for the nomination include Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, former envoy to the United Nations Nikki Haley, and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy.

item.title: Why are my kids good around other people and then badly behaved with me?
item.description: This article discusses why children often behave well at school or in other settings but exhibit worse behavior at home. It explains that children learn from an early age that their behavior produces outcomes and can be a way to control the actions of others. Sometimes, children are inadvertently rewarded for misbehavior at home through increased attention or getting what they want. In contrast, children may behave better at school because teachers have clear expectations and reward systems in place. The article suggests that parents can help improve their children's behavior at home by establishing routines, setting simple house rules, noticing good behavior, spending regular small amounts of time with their child, and having realistic expectations.

item.title: What do people in the Pacific really think of China? It’s more nuanced than you may imagine
item.description: China's increasing presence in the Pacific region has led to mixed perceptions among local populations, according to surveys conducted in Papua New Guinea (PNG) and the Solomon Islands. While both governments welcome China's engagement, concerns over environmental pollution and perceived lack of benefits from Chinese projects were raised. However, those living near mining operations tended to view them more positively due to financial benefits. Chinese government scholarships improved students' views of China, with participants recommending the program and reporting a positive change in their impressions of the country. In the Solomon Islands, support for closer ties with both China and the US was high among surveyed students, although some expressed concerns about potential debt risks associated with China's Belt and Road Initiative. Non-governmental organizations in the Pacific also raised concerns about human rights violations, governance, debt risks, and environmental pollution related to China's initiatives. The complex and nuanced perceptions of local populations in the Pacific regarding China's influence should be considered by policymakers in the US and Australia as they aim to counter China's growing relationships in the region.

item.title: Thane man orders smartphone online, receives soap bars instead

item.title: What do people in the Pacific really think of China? It’s more nuanced than you may imagine
item.description: Hmm, based on the provided text, it seems that China has been increasing its presence in the Pacific region, particularly in countries like Papua New Guinea (PNG) and Solomon Islands. While the governments of these countries welcome China's engagement, there are mixed perceptions among the local populations. For example, in PNG, concerns about environmental pollution related to the China-owned Ramu NiCo project were expressed by the majority of respondents. However, those living in the mining lease area had a more positive view due to the direct financial benefits they receive. In Solomon Islands, there is support for a closer bilateral relationship with China, but some individuals have concerns about debt risks and Chinese control over resources. It's important for policymakers in the US and Australia to understand these nuanced perceptions as they navigate China's growing influence in the region.

item.title: Soccer-Australia aim to top World Cup qualifying: Behich
item.description: Australia aims to secure top spot in their Asia groups during World Cup qualifying in order to avoid a difficult route to the 2026 finals in North America, according to defender Aziz Behich. Australia had to win playoffs against the United Arab Emirates and Honduras to reach the previous World Cups in Qatar and Russia, respectively. While the expanded 48-team World Cup in 2026 offers Asia eight direct qualifying spots, Behich emphasized the team's goal of topping their group. Australia, ranked 27th in the world and fourth in Asia, begins qualifying against Bangladesh in Melbourne. The team is eager to play in front of home fans after being forced to play abroad for much of the Qatar qualifying cycle due to COVID-19 restrictions.

item.title: In the Market: Inside Wall Street’s scramble after ICBC hack
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) experienced a significant cyber hack on its U.S. broker-dealer, causing disruption to its operations. The attack was so extensive that the corporate email system stopped working, forcing employees to switch to Google mail. As a result, the brokerage temporarily owed BNY Mellon $9 billion, which was much larger than its net capital. ICBC's New York-based unit received financial support from its Chinese parent to repay BNY Mellon, and manual processing of trades was conducted with the help of the custody bank. ICBC expected the process of setting up secure systems and resuming normal business to take at least until Monday. During this time, clients were asked to temporarily suspend business and clear trades elsewhere. The ransomware attack, claimed by cybercrime gang Lockbit, raises concerns about the resilience of the Treasury market and highlights the importance of cybersecurity. The hack may also influence regulatory discussions surrounding central clearing of Treasury trades. The incident is likely to be a topic of conversation at an upcoming Treasury market conference. Despite being a mid-sized broker, ICBC's systems being paralyzed caused disruptions in the market, leading some market participants to reroute their trades. BNY Mellon played a crucial role in helping sort through the situation and facilitated the clearing of trades manually. ICBC's parent injected capital into the unit to ensure payment to BNY Mellon. Once ICBC's new system is operational, others in the industry will also review its safety measures, potentially causing further delays in returning to normal operations.

item.title: Payments app Zelle begins refunds for imposter scams after Washington pressure
item.description:
Banks on the payment app Zelle have made a significant policy change by starting to refund victims of imposter scams. This decision comes in response to concerns raised by U.S. lawmakers and the federal consumer watchdog. Zelle, which is owned by seven major banks including JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, began reversing transfers on June 30 for customers who were deceived into sending money to scammers posing as government agencies or financial service providers. The move goes beyond legal requirements, according to Ben Chance, the chief fraud risk officer at Early Warning Services (EWS), the company that owns Zelle.
Previously, banks were only required to reimburse customers for unauthorized payments made by hackers, not for transfers initiated by customers themselves. While Zelle introduced a new reimbursement benefit for specific scam types, it had not previously provided details about its imposter scam refund policy due to concerns that it could encourage false scam claims.
This policy shift represents a significant change from last year when banks argued against refunding transfers that customers were tricked into approving. Zelle has faced criticism after a New York Times report highlighted the prevalence of scams on their platform, with Senator Elizabeth Warren estimating that Zelle users lost $440 million to fraud in 2021 alone.
Impersonator fraud was the most-reported scam across all payment methods in the U.S. in 2022, resulting in $2.6 billion in losses, according to the Federal Trade Commission. Despite concerns that covering the cost of authorized transactions might lead to more fraud, Zelle's owner company, EWS, has implemented a mechanism that allows banks to recover funds from the recipient's account and return them to the sender. Additionally, Zelle now requires lenders to implement a tool that detects transfers with risky attributes.
Zelle's changes have satisfied the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) so far, but pressure from lawmakers may lead to further rule changes to protect customers from scams. Zelle faces market pressure to improve its standards of care as it competes with other peer-to-peer payment platforms like PayPal and Venmo, which offer purchase protection programs for eligible transactions.
While Zelle's policy change is seen as a positive step, experts emphasize that regulations mandating imposter fraud protections would be better to ensure customer well-being. Payment fraud is expected to be a topic of discussion when bank CEOs appear before the Senate in the future.

item.title: China’s Didi swings to third-quarter profit, to buy-back $1 billion worth of shares
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.China's largest ride-hailing company, Didi Global, posted a profit of 107 million yuan ($14.66 million) in the third quarter of this year, compared to a loss of 2.01 billion yuan in the same period last year. This improvement was driven by increased domestic demand for mobility services. Didi Global also announced plans for share repurchases worth up to $1 billion over the next two years. Revenue for the company rose by 25% to reach 51.40 billion yuan.

item.title: Dollar steady ahead of US inflation data, yen near one-year low
item.description: The dollar remained strong as traders awaited U.S. inflation data to gauge the Federal Reserve's response to price pressures. The Japanese yen stayed weak, close to a one-year low, amidst speculation of possible intervention by Tokyo. The focus for traders will be on the U.S. consumer price index (CPI) numbers, with more Fed speakers expected to leave room for further interest rate hikes. Moody's lowering of the U.S. credit rating outlook had little impact on the market. The yen was pressured by rising U.S. treasury yields and continued dollar strength. Wholesale inflation in Japan slowed below 1%, suggesting fading cost pressures. Sterling held firm ahead of UK economic data releases, while the euro hovered around $1.0688.

item.title: Yen hits fresh one-year low as focus swings to US inflation data
item.description: The Japanese yen reached a one-year low against the dollar as traders eagerly awaited U.S. inflation data, which is expected to provide insight into whether the Federal Reserve needs to take further action to control rising prices. Market analysts believe that even if the CPI numbers are softer, the Fed will continue to resist rate cuts, considering inflation remains above target. Moody's recent announcement of lowering its outlook for the U.S. credit rating had little impact on the market. The yen remained under pressure due to increasing U.S. Treasury yields and a strong dollar. Meanwhile, data from Japan indicated that wholesale inflation had slowed below 1% for the first time in over two years, suggesting fading cost pressures that offered little support to the yen. In other news, sterling held steady ahead of UK earnings data, while the euro hovered around $1.0688.

item.title: Indonesia’s Prabowo stretches lead in new survey on presidential contenders
item.description: Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto has taken a significant lead over his rival in a recent opinion poll, despite controversy surrounding his choice of running mate, the son of the outgoing leader Joko Widodo. The survey conducted by Indikator Politik Indonesia showed that 39.7% of respondents would vote for Prabowo, while 30% would support the ruling party's Ganjar Pranowo. The inclusion of Widodo's son in the race has been seen by some analysts as a strategy to help retain political influence and boost support for Prabowo. The survey also indicated that younger voters and Jokowi loyalists are increasingly backing Prabowo.

item.title: Tamil Nadu: Customs at Trichy Airport seize gold worth over Rs 1 crores from two passengers
item.description: Customs officials at Trichy Airport in Tamil Nadu, India, have seized gold worth over one crore rupees from two separate passengers. In the first incident, seven gold biscuits weighing 700 grams and gold jewellery weighing 94 grams were confiscated from a male passenger arriving from Singapore. The value of the seized gold was approximately 47,75,400 rupees. In another incident, gold weighing around 995.500 grams, valued at 60,42,685 rupees, was extracted from paste-like materials concealed in the rectum of a male passenger arriving from Dubai.

item.title: Pakistan’s National Institute of Health issues awareness, communication alert for Human Leptospirosis
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Pakistan's National Institute of Health (NIH) has issued an alert for human leptospirosis, a bacterial disease that affects humans and animals. The objective of the advisory is to ensure early detection and timely management of leptospirosis cases. Leptospirosis is a rare zoonotic bacterial disease transmitted from animals, mostly rodents, pets, cattle, and wild animals, to humans through contact with infected animal excreta. The disease is more common in tropical and subtropical areas with high rainfall. Although sporadic cases have been reported in Pakistan, person-to-person transmission is very rare.

In a separate operation in Tank, Dera Ismail Khan, four terrorists were killed in a shootout with the police.

Three babies died in the neonatal unit of Al-Shifa hospital due to Israeli fire, causing the hospital to go out of service. The hospital complex is surrounded, and essential departments, such as the intensive care unit and pediatric department, have stopped working. item.title: Tennis-Superb Fernandez seals Canada’s first BJK Cup title
item.description: Canada's Leylah Fernandez led her team to their first Billie Jean King Cup title by securing the decisive point in a 2-0 victory over Italy. Fernandez continued her impressive performance throughout the week, defeating Jasmine Paolini 6-2 6-3. The Canadian team celebrated their historic win on court in front of jubilant fans. Prior to Fernandez's victory, teenager Marina Stakusic had contributed to Canada's success by defeating Martina Trevisan in a stunning match. Despite some hiccups, Stakusic maintained her composure and closed out the game with a powerful forehand winner. Fernandez's heroics against the Czech Republic in the semifinals also played a crucial role in Canada's journey to the final. She teamed up with Gabriela Dabrowski to secure another victory in doubles. Fernandez attributed the team's success to their hard work and improvement over the years. As the new champions, Canada received a record-breaking $2.4 million in prize money. They were presented with the trophy by Billie Jean King herself and hailed as deserving world champions. Canada is now the 13th nation to win the Billie Jean King Cup, following Switzerland's victory the previous year.

item.title: Soccer-Chelsea take leap forward in 4-4 draw with Man City
item.description: Chelsea's 4-4 draw with Manchester City in the Premier League showcased their progress under manager Mauricio Pochettino. Despite falling behind three times, Chelsea fought back each time and secured a late equalizer through a penalty. The match saw several lead changes, with both teams displaying attacking prowess. While the point earned by Chelsea left them in 10th place, the performance demonstrated their improvement. Pochettino acknowledged that there is still a long way to go but expressed hope for future progress. City coach Pep Guardiola praised Chelsea's performance and acknowledged their potential as they continue to rebuild.

item.title: Pakistan: Justice (retd) Arshad Hussain Shah sworn in as KP caretaker chief minister
item.description: Justice (Retd) Arshad Hussain Shah has been sworn in as the caretaker Chief Minister of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) in Pakistan, following the passing of former Chief Executive Azam Khan. The oath was administered by KP Governor Haji Ghulam Ali, and the appointment was agreed upon by former Chief Minister Mahmood Khan and former opposition leader Akram Khan Durrani. Shah had previously served as the Law Minister in Khan's cabinet and as the Chief Justice of Gilgit-Baltistan. Interim Prime Minister Anwaarul Haq Kakar congratulated Shah on his appointment and expressed hope that he would support the province's administrative affairs and electoral processes.

item.title: Soccer-Israel beaten 1-0 by Kosovo in rescheduled Euro qualifier
item.description: Israel lost 1-0 to Kosovo in their European Championship qualifier match in Pristina. The game was originally scheduled for October 15 but was delayed due to the Hamas-Israel conflict. Israel recognized Kosovo as a sovereign state in 2020, and both countries have diplomatic relations. Despite a rocky start and crowd booing during their national anthem, Israel tried to score with shots from Dor Peretz and Eran Zahavi. However, Kosovo took the lead with a goal by Milot Rashica in the 41st minute. Israel pushed for an equalizer but finished the game with 10 men after Roy Revivo was sent off in the 95th minute. Israel will play their next two qualifiers in Hungary against Switzerland and Romania. Romania currently tops the group with 16 points, followed by Switzerland with 15 points.

item.title: Soccer-Inter beat Frosinone 2-0 to return to Serie A summit
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Inter Milan reclaimed the top spot in Serie A with a 2-0 home win over Frosinone. The victory was secured by a long-range strike from Federico Dimarco and a penalty by Hakan Calhanoglu. Dimarco broke the deadlock just before halftime with a lob that sailed over the Frosinone keeper. Calhanoglu extended Inter's lead three minutes into the second half with a converted penalty. The win sent Inter back to the top of the table with 31 points, two points clear of Juventus in second place. Frosinone is currently in 12th place with 15 points.

item.title: Soccer-Atletico fight back to grab 3-1 win over Villarreal
item.description: Atletico Madrid defeated Villarreal 3-1 in a La Liga match, with late goals from Antoine Griezmann and Samuel Lino. Atletico currently sits in fourth place, two points behind Barcelona in third and four points behind surprise leaders Girona. Villarreal took an early lead but Atletico equalized just before halftime, thanks to a goal by Axel Witsel. Griezmann scored the winning goal in the 80th minute, and Lino sealed the victory with another goal five minutes from time. Griezmann, who has been in excellent form, has scored eight goals in 12 La Liga matches this season.

item.title: Australia’s TPG Telecom ends $4 billion fibre sale talks with Vocus
item.description: Australian telecom company TPG Telecom has ended discussions with rival Vocus Group regarding the sale of its non-mobile fibre assets for AUD 6.3 billion as the two parties failed to reach an agreement on commercial terms. Vocus had made a non-binding offer to acquire certain assets and fixed infrastructure from TPG, but issues around the operating model led to the deal's collapse. TPG will continue its strategic review and says it has received strong interest from potential investors in its fixed infrastructure assets. This setback follows the blocking of a previous asset swap deal with Telstra Group.

The North Korean report also criticized a joint declaration being adopted for contingencies in the Korean peninsula. This criticism comes after a trilateral meeting between the US, South Korea, and Japan, where they condemned North Korea's military cooperation with Russia as a violation of UN resolutions.

item.title: More Gaza hospitals suspend operations as Israel hunts Hamas

Hospitals are struggling to cope with constant gunfire and bombing. Israel claims that Hamas has placed command centers under and near the hospitals, but Hamas denies this. The humanitarian situation in Gaza is worsening, with disease spreading among evacuees living in overcrowded shelters. Aid deliveries have been limited, but some aid trucks have entered Gaza from Egypt, and Jordan has air-dropped supplies into a field hospital. The conflict in Gaza has also reignited clashes on Israel's northern border with Lebanon.

item.title: Trapped Brazilians, whose fate hurt Israel-Brazil ties, leave Gaza
item.description: A group of 32 Brazilians and their families, who had been trapped in Gaza for weeks, have crossed the border into Egypt. The Brazilian foreign ministry announced that they were received by the Brazilian embassy in Cairo and are expected to return to Brazil on Monday. However, two members of the group decided to stay for personal reasons. The release of the trapped Brazilians was a point of contention between Brazil and Israel, which escalated when the Israeli spy agency Mossad claimed it helped foil a Hezbollah attack in Brazil. This incident, along with an appearance by Israel's ambassador to Brazil alongside former President Jair Bolsonaro, strained relations between the two countries.

item.title: New Zealand Prime Minister-elect unlikely to attend APEC as coalition talks continue
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.New Zealand's Prime Minister-elect, Christopher Luxon, stated that he is unlikely to attend the upcoming APEC meeting in San Francisco due to ongoing coalition negotiations. Although Luxon's conservative National Party won the largest share of votes in last month's general election, they require the support of both the right-wing ACT New Zealand and populist New Zealand First Parties to form a majority government. While talks have intensified since the release of final election results on November 3, there is still no set timeline for reaching an agreement. Luxon believes that progress is being made and wants to focus on concluding negotiations and forming a government. However, he expressed a desire to attend APEC to showcase New Zealand as open for business and establish relationships with world leaders. If Luxon doesn't attend, New Zealand will send representatives from the caretaker government and the National Party. The process of forming a government in New Zealand typically takes about a month but can sometimes take longer under the country's mixed member proportional system.

item.title: Biden, Qatari emir discuss Gaza, agree all hostages must be released
item.description: U.S. President Joe Biden spoke with Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani regarding the situation in Gaza and efforts to secure the release of hostages held by Hamas. Biden strongly condemned the holding of hostages, including a 3-year-old American citizen whose parents were killed by Hamas. Both leaders emphasized the need for the immediate release of all hostages. Israeli officials reported that Hamas fighters crossed into Israel, killing around 1,200 people and taking over 200 hostages. The Israeli bombardment of Gaza has resulted in the deaths of more than 11,000 Palestinians, many of them children. Qatar has been leading mediation efforts between Hamas and Israeli officials. Negotiations involving Israel, Qatar, Egypt, and the United States are ongoing to secure the release of the remaining hostages. U.S. officials are uncertain about the status of the missing individuals but are working towards their safe recovery. Biden's national security adviser will meet with the families of the American hostages. A U.S. official stated that visits are planned to Israel, Brussels, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, and Qatar. Qatar called for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and the permanent opening of the Rafah crossing into Egypt during the call with Biden. The White House statement did not mention discussions about a ceasefire but focused on protecting civilians and increasing humanitarian assistance. Biden reaffirmed his vision for a future Palestinian state and acknowledged Hamas as an obstacle to achieving stability. Both leaders agreed to continue working towards a peaceful and prosperous Middle East.

item.title: US carries out air strikes in Syria against Iran-linked facilities
item.description: The United States carried out two airstrikes in Syria against Iran and its aligned groups in response to attacks against American forces. The strikes targeted a training facility near Albu Kamal and a safe house near Mayadeen. U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin stated that President Joe Biden ordered the strikes to protect American personnel and interests. Local sources reported that the strikes also targeted a camp run by pro-Iranian militias. These airstrikes are part of the United States' efforts to address the ongoing wave of drone and rocket attacks on its troops in Iraq and Syria. Iran and its supporters argue that the U.S. shares responsibility for Israel's conflict with the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which is also backed by Iran.

Ukrainian military intelligence reported an explosion in the Russian-occupied town of Melitopol, where three Russian servicemen were killed. Zelenskiy issued the warning after Russian forces carried out their first missile attack on the capital, Kyiv, in seven weeks. Ukrainian officials have said that Russia has already struck Ukrainian infrastructure 60 times in recent weeks. The Ukrainian military has been increasingly active in attacking Russian-held areas but does not always acknowledge the strikes.

It also notes a lack of transparency, including the omission of party chiefs' names on websites and the failure to share party constitutions online. This digital deficiency allows for the spread of propaganda and hate speech in online political discourse. The report indicates a lack of digital literacy among political leaders and a trend where inflammatory rhetoric takes precedence over inclusive communication.

item.title: Deepika Padukone-Ranveer Singh extend Diwali greetings with adorable pictures, Check out

They both looked stunning in traditional attire—Ranveer in a white kurta with a floral print jacket, and Deepika in a pink suit. Fans flooded the comment section with love and fire emojis upon seeing the pictures. Ranveer and Deepika got married in November 2018 after dating for six years and often express their love for each other on social media. They met on the sets of "Goliyon Ki Rasleela Ram-Leela" and have since worked together in films like "Bajirao Mastani" and "Padmaavat." Deepika has upcoming projects such as "Kalki 2898 AD," "Fighter," and "Singham Again," while Ranveer will appear in "Don 3."

item.title: Wankhede is a tough venue to bowl, we need early wickets against NZ: Kuldeep
item.description: Ahead of their World Cup semifinals against New Zealand, Indian spinner Kuldeep Yadav said that the Wankhede stadium is a tough venue for bowlers and early wickets will be crucial for India to gain an advantage. He dismissed the significance of past records and expressed confidence in India's preparation and performance. Kuldeep has been a key player in India's spin department, taking 14 wickets with a good economy rate. India's fielding coach also praised KL Rahul for his wicket-keeping skills since returning from a long injury layoff.

item.title: To keep lively dressing room atmosphere, you need good results: Rohit
item.description: Indian cricket team captain, Rohit Sharma, expressed the importance of enjoying each other's company in the dressing room and how it contributes to their success. He described their campaign in the World Cup as clinical and attributed their good results to the lively atmosphere in the team. India topped the league standings with 18 points and will face New Zealand in the semifinals. Rohit also highlighted the team's adaptability to different venues and their focus on taking one game at a time. Shreyas Iyer, who was named player of the match, emphasized his determination not to throw away his wicket and capitalized on his start. Netherlands captain, Scott Edwards, praised India's batting performance, acknowledging their class. He also discussed the future of his team and their focus on learning from the tournament.

Modi commended the team's skill and teamwork and expressed his joy on Diwali.

item.title: “Look good, feel better, dance a lot tonight”: SRK extends Diwali greetings to fans
item.description: Superstar Shah Rukh Khan extended heartfelt Diwali greetings to his fans, expressing gratitude for the gift of life and calling for strength, forgiveness, and blessings. He shared this message on Twitter and encouraged everyone to look good, feel better, and dance a lot during the festival. Diwali, also known as the festival of lights, symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. The article mentions that people across India have decorated their houses with lights, rangolis, and flowers in celebration. The report also highlights SRK's upcoming film 'Dunki', directed by Rajkumar Hirani, which features Vicky Kaushal, Taapsee Pannu, and Boman Irani in lead roles. The film is set to release on Christmas 2023.

item.title: After dismal progress in BRI, China switches to ‘regional approach’ in Nepal: Report
item.description: China is taking a regional approach to extend its Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in Nepal after six years of slow progress, according to the Kathmandu Post. Wang Junzheng, the regional secretary of the Communist Party of China for Tibet, visited Nepal and met with its chief minister, indicating China's direct engagement with a provincial government. The visit aims to implement agreements signed between Nepal and China during recent high-level visits. The Chinese delegation also expressed interest in helping Nepal operate the Pokhara International Airport by initiating regular flights from Chinese cities. Additionally, they discussed trade, connectivity, tourism, and people-to-people contact. The Chinese leaders invited the chief minister to visit Tibet and expressed their commitment to supporting Nepal after the recent earthquake. This regional approach aligns with China's strategy for executing the BRI, with Tibet playing a leading role due to its proximity to Nepal.

Jaishankar is currently on an official visit to the UK and will also meet with his UK counterpart James Cleverly. India and the UK have a growing bilateral partnership and are negotiating a Free Trade Agreement. During a telephone conversation, Modi and Sunak discussed the progress on the Free Trade Agreement and the ongoing Cricket World Cup. They also discussed the conflict in West Asia and the need to de-escalate tensions in the region.

item.title: Highly decomposed body of driver found inside truck; cops suspect heart attack
item.description: The decomposed body of a 56-year-old man named Nivrutti Chavan was found at the steering wheel of his truck in Kandivali, Mumbai. There were no signs of injury, and it is believed that he may have died from a heart attack. The police were alerted by the foul smell coming from the truck, and Chavan's identity was confirmed using documents found in the vehicle. An accidental death report has been filed, and the article concludes with a note about supporting journalism.

item.title: Six persons, including four firemen, injured in leopard attack in Tamil Nadu
item.description: Six people, including four fire and rescue services personnel, were injured in a leopard attack in Coonoor. The leopard had strayed into a human habitat and took refuge in a woman's house. The injured individuals were rescued by nearby residents and are currently receiving treatment at a local hospital. A driver of the local tahsildar was also attacked by the leopard. Efforts are underway to trap the animal, with two cages placed outside the house.Six people, including four Fire and Rescue Services personnel, were injured in a leopard attack in Coonoor, Nilgiris.
